By May 9, 2016, she had surrendered seven more. An incident report from January 2014 states her home was a "chronic problem." No charges were filed.
Legislation info: This case sparked investigations and changes in several city departments because of failures to communicate between agencies.

Reported Breed: dogs (1 American Bulldog and her 9 Belgian Malinois-AmBulldog cross offspring)
Incident info: Victim was a caretaker at a farm and was killed where he worked and the dogs lived. Victim's girlfriend witnessed the attack and called 911. Victim was airlifted to the hospital and died 6 hours later. The witness said three dogs instigated the attack and the others joined in.
Dog-disposition: Nearly one month after a man was mauled to death by a pack of dogs, Miami-Dade Animal Services (MDAS) finally seized the animals. During the interim, one of the dogs threatened an officer and was shot and killed. 9 dogs were eventually seized, including the pack's dam (mother), described as an American Bulldog by MDAS. The offspring were 8 months old.

Incident info: Two parents were watching television in bed with their newborn son and the 80# dog. The mother coughed, and the dog attacked the newborn child. After a struggle to get Polo to release their child's skull, and two unanswered 911 calls, the parents drove the infant to a hospital where he was pronounced dead.
Dog-disposition: Polo, 2-year-old neutered family dog, which had been adopted from the San Diego Humane Society five months previously after passing a SAFER temperament test. The dog was quarantined by San Diego County Animal Services, which euthanized it days later, at the request of the owners.

Reported Breed: dogs (3 pit bulls mixes, 2 mixed breed)
Incident info: Victim was found dead of animal bites in a dry canal. Less than two months later, another victim, 74-year old Robert Lee Simonian, was found dead in the same canal, now wet. Though Simonian died of drowning, he too was covered in dog bites. Both men were found about 100 yards from a dog owner's house, and loose dogs were harassing responders, search and rescue personnel, and neighbors.
Dog-disposition: After a hearing on the dogs, five dogs were declared dangerous and ordered to be euthanized.

Incident info: Severely attacked by her own 100# dog and bleeding on her back porch, victim was found by her daughter-in-law who called 911. The dog threatened paramedics so police were called. The police shot and killed the dog with a rifle from atop the fire truck. The victim lived alone with her four dogs.
Dog-disposition: Hercules was given to the victim as a puppy by her son, who lives next door. The 100# dog was shot by responding police officers.
Owner info & disposition: Victim. In three separate incidents in 2008, 2012 and 2014, children were attacked by dogs from the same household.

Incident info: While visiting her daughter's home, Flowers slipped or fell onto a dog's bed. The two dogs initially seemed to play with the victim then became increasingly aggressive, biting her head and neck, and causing substantial blood loss. According to the Medical Examiner's Office, Flowers died of "blunt force neck injuries due to dog attack."
Dog-disposition: Animal control officers seized both pit bulls, a male and female, and were later euthanized.
Owner info & disposition: Daughter of victim. Police had been called to the same address in 2013 regarding a complaint about two aggressive dogs. A neighbor told news reporters that there were two earlier incidents with the same dogs where they attacked other dogs.

Incident info: Victim went to neighbor's house to deliver a newspaper, opened the door to enter, and four dogs attacked. It wasn't unusual for the victim to do that, but this time the owner wasn't home. The owner arrived home during the attack. Victim died two days later after a prognosis of two limb amputations.
Dog-disposition: The four dogs were seized and were euthanized after a 10-day quarantine period.
Owner info & disposition: One dog belonged to the victim's neighbor-friend. The other three dogs were being cared for by the neighbor but belonged to the neighbor's daughter who had been jailed just three days before the attack.

Incident info: The victim was mauled to death inside her home by her 1½-year-old 100# male dog. The dog had attacked her while she was cleaning its crate; her sister (her roommate) heard her screams and pulled the dog off her and shut it in a bathroom. The dog broke a hole in the bathroom door, escaped, and resumed its attack, holding her down, mauling her, and ripping her throat out. The victim died just as the medical helicopter arrived. The victim leaves behind her two teenage daughters.
Owner info & disposition: The victim had acquired Buddy two weeks before the fatal attack from a newspaper ad placed by his former owners, Cheryl and Carl Davino. A man online claiming to be the dog's breeder, called Mike Brown, told reporters Davino had told Brown that she sold Buddy after he attacked her small dog; Davino never mentioned Buddy's violent attack to Story.

Incident info: The mother woke up from the couch where she was sleeping with the baby in a basket next to her. The baby was screaming, covered in blood. The baby was dead by the tie police arrived. Two other adults were home at the time, and a total of five dogs.
Dog-disposition: The male dog was later declared vicious and returned.
Owner info & disposition: The victim's brother. No criminal charges were filed.

Reported Breed: dogs (1 Pit bull mix + 2 mixed breed dogs)
Incident info: While playing with his siblings in a field behind their home, the boys were attacked by three dogs. The older brother was able to escape further injury by jumping on a car, but the victim could not escape the attack. The male pit bull broke the boy's neck, killing him.
Dog-disposition: The three dogs tested negative for rabies. The male pit bull died at the scene due to over-exertion with an advanced case of heartworms. The other two, females, were euthanized. One of the females had recently had a litter and the puppies were taken to an unnamed rescue.
Legislation info: Five months later, the city modified their dog ordinance to include dog registrations, mandatory neutering, limit the number of dogs kept at any household to three, and labelled several pit bull breeds as "potentially vicious" requiring them to be kept indoors or in a secure outside pen with a concrete floor, and mandating liability insurance.

Incident info: Victim was attacked while under the care of her babysitters. The dog, which belonged to the babysitters, bit Payton in the head. She was airlifted to a hospital and died two days later.
Dog-disposition: The dog, E.J., was seized. Witnesses reported they had previously seen the dog aggressive with humans and animals.
Owner info & disposition: John Terry Underwood II and Terra Lynn Connell, the babysitters. At the time of the attack, they were charged with felony child neglect and possessing a vicious dog. Connell was also charged with possession of illegal drugs and possession of ammunition by a felon. After the baby died, the couple were charged with second-degree murder. In separate trials, Underwood, 52, was sentenced to 25 years in prison (with 18 years suspended), after being found guilty of failing to contain a vicious dog, resulting in serious human injury; felony child neglect; and involuntary manslaughter. Connell was ordered to serve 15 years behind bars and a suspended sentence of seven years. Connell's sentence includes a 10-year sentence for involuntary manslaughter, a 10-year sentence for felony child endangerment (with five years suspended) and two years (suspended) for possessing a dangerous dog. Both had been held without bond since the fatal dog mauling.

Incident info: The boy was killed while visiting his older sister, Alexandria Griffin-Heady. He was left alone for several hours with her three pit bulls in makeshift cages in a small delapidated RV trailer. They broke free and mauled the boy before the sister came home.
Dog-disposition: All three pit bulls were euthanized. Griffin-Heady had raised the pit bulls, a mother and two offspring, since they were puppies.
Owner info & disposition: Alexandria Griffin-Heady, the victim's older sister. The District Attorney declined to file charges, nor even bring the case before a Grand Jury. Griffin-Heady was pursuing custody of her younger brother, who was living in foster care; her family says she was "ill-equipped to care for a young boy", and her aunt told child welfare officials that her niece was "unstable". Tyler was in protective custody, living at a foster home under the care of Sacramento County Child Protection Services. Recently, CPS had begun granting unsupervised overnight visits with his sister and her pit bulls who lived in a small trailer that sat adjacent to a home where two of Tyler's siblings lived.
Legislation info: Citing Tyler’s death, state assemblyman Kevin McCarthy called for an oversight hearing of the child welfare system, which he said allows "too many kids to slip through the cracks and die."

Incident info: The girl was visiting her father at his home when his 95 pound dog attacked her in the hallway. The girl's grandmother called the dog a pit bull on social media, but Animal Services said it was an American Bulldog mix. Miami-Dade County prohibits pit bulls.
Dog-disposition: Unknown.

Incident info: Deputies found victim's body when they arrived for a welfare check because she didn't report to work that day. She had been mauled by her two pet dogs, presumably while trying to break up a fight between them. Both dogs had injuries consistent with a recent dog fight
Dog-disposition: Two unneutered male pit bulls, 3 and 5 years old. The dogs were surrendered by family members and euthanized.

Incident info: Victim was out riding his bicycle and was later found critically injured and barely conscious on the side of the road. Authorities had thought he was attacked by a large wild animal. Hospitalized, and after emerging from unconsciousness after multiple surgeries, he told authorities he was attacked by a pack of dogs. He died several weeks later from his injuries.
Dog-disposition: DNA results linked all four of boxers to the mauling death. By the time investigators wanted to take DNA samples from the dogs, the owner had given one away through Craigslist and another was dropped at a county shelter. The latter dog was a perfect DNA match to saliva found on the victim's clothes.
Owner info & disposition: Joseph Brink and his wife Lindsay Brink. Two years after the attack, a grand jury indicted the Brinks on second-degree manslaughter, stating they were aware of the aggressive disposition of the dogs and failed to maintain adequate control of the dogs by allowing them to run at large.
Legislation info: In August 2017, the Brinks agreed to a $300,000 settlement after the victim's son filed a wrongful-death civil lawsuit.

Incident info: The medical examiner ruled the death a suicide. A witness said he saw the victim put one leg over the decrepit fence of a neighbor's property, and while still on the fence the pit bull grabbed her leg, pulled her over, and began attacking her. Then a white husky in the yard also started attacking the victim. The owner came out and beat the pit bull with a 2-by-4, ending the attack. An investigation revealed that the victim knew the dogs were dangerous.
Dog-disposition: Both dogs were destroyed, along with several puppies from their mating.
Owner info & disposition: Andrew Scott Miller and Jessica Rae Johnson were charged with having unlicensed dogs, a misdemeanor which carries a 90-day sentence and/or a $500 fine.

Incident info: Victim was killed by four pit bulls as he walked down a residential sidewalk with his mother when multiple pit bulls escaped under their owner's gate, snatched the boy from his mother's arms, dragged him across the street then yanked him back under the gate and disemboweled him. His mother witnessed his brutal murder and was also severely injured by one of the dogs while trying to save her son.
Dog-disposition: A responding police officer open fire, killing three of the pit bulls. The fourth was confiscated and later destroyed. The dogs had a history of escaping their owner's property. Neighbors say the dogs routinely escaped the property and terrorized locals.
Owner info & disposition: Geneke Antonio Lyons, 41. Five days later, he was charged with second-degree murder, manslaughter and possessing dangerous animals causing death. Bond was set at $1 Million.
Legislation info: The boy's parents filed two lawsuits against the dogs' owner and the property owner. The newspapers published editorials asking the city to once again examine Detroit's enduring pit bull problem.

Incident info: Victim was was killed by the family pit bull while he and his three sisters, ages 7, 10 and 12, were playing with the dog in the living room. The mother had turned her back momentarily then heard screams from her children. When she saw the dog attacking her baby, she tried to get it to release its jaws, then called 911. The baby was rushed to hospital where he died due to facial and neck injuries.
Dog-disposition: Diesel, the family dog, was seized, quarantined, and euthanized at the family's request. It had not shown aggression since joining the family 2-years prior as a puppy.

Incident info: Victim was attacked and killed by a dog he had adopted just a few hours earlier from his local shelter. After leaving the shelter, he took the dog to show it to his son. About 3-hours later, His wife called him. With no answer, she arrived home with a co-worker and found her husband dead on the floor. The dog then attacked the wife and her co-worker, biting them both.
Dog-disposition: The 5 year old Rottweiler was shot and killed on scene by Sheriff's deputies after it ran out of the house. Rabies Control had picked up the dog 5-days earlier as a stray with an unknown history. The county agency has no evaluation or temperament testing policy before placing a dog up for adoption to the public.

Incident info: Victim was attacked by five dogs when he went to a friend's rental home to take out the trash. The pit bulls jumped their fence and charged him. He tried to hold a gate closed, blocking the dogs, but the dogs found a hole in the fence and resumed their attack. While hospitalized, victim's condition deteriorated. In addition to suffering a heart attack, doctors were forced to amputate both of his legs and part of one arm due to infection. He died twelve days after the attack.
Dog-disposition: All five dogs were euthanized.
Owner info & disposition: Juan Marcos Diaz, 46, pleaded guilty to second-degree manslaughter and was sentenced to one year in prison and three years probation.
Legislation info: The victim's estate won a $15M civil case against the dogs' owner.

Incident info: Victim was attacked while playing with two other girls in the backyard of her biological father's home. When police arrived, the pit bull was still engaged in its assault - the dog latched onto her neck and head, and fiercely shook her. Victim died at hospital with bite wounds all over her body.
Dog-disposition: Kane, a 2 year old male pit bull, was shot and killed by responding officers.
Owner info & disposition: Carlyle Arnold, 29, a tenant on the property, was arrested at the scene for an unrelated charge.

Incident info: Victim and his mother were visiting a friend's home. Tanner was jumping on a trampoline in the fenced-in yard when one of the pit bulls ran into the home covered in blood. Victim's mother rushed outside and found her son critically injured. The dogs attacked his face and neck, severing his carotid artery. Ashley believed the dogs' owner was with her son while playing outside, but he was not present during the attack.
Dog-disposition: The owner shot and killed both dogs once he learned what happened. In 2014, the same dogs attacked a neighbor's puppy, and in February 2015, the dogs escaped their property and attacked a 9-year old girl and her mother. The girl's injuries were not considered severe enough by authorities to deem the dogs "dangerous."

Incident info: Victim was attacked and killed by a chained dog after wandering into his neighbor's unfenced backyard. He had been playing with several other children inside and outside a cluster of nearby homes when the 2-year old slipped away. He was discovered badly injured by the dog's owner.Victim was attacked and killed by a chained dog after wandering into his neighbor's unfenced backyard. He had been playing with several other children inside and outside a cluster of nearby homes when the 2-year old slipped away. He was discovered badly injured by the dog's owner.
Dog-disposition: The dog, 1 year old Bubba, was surrendered for euthanisia. The owners also surrendered the attacking dog's dam to the shelter for possible rehoming.
Owner info & disposition: Joseph Creamer and Debra Snow were backyard breeders of pit bulls. No criminal charges were brought.

Reported Breed: dogs (1 American Bulldog mix + 1 Rhodesian Ridgeback mix + 1 Lab-Shepherd mix)
Incident info: The woman was found in her home in a pool of blood, missing the skin off of her scalp and most of her face, with bites on her head, neck, arms and legs. A forensic dentist matched the mouths of all three of the household dogs to the bite marks. The autopsy report said victim died of dog bites to the head, neck and extremities; that the victim had a defleshed face and scalp; and that the victim suffered multiple rib fractures, lacerations to her liver and lungs, and contusions to her liver, lungs and heart.
Dog-disposition: Miami-Dade Animal Services seized the three dogs: Bear,an American bulldog mix; Jack, a Rhodesian ridgeback mix, Marli, a labrador-shepherd mix. The were ordered euthanized at a dangerous dog hearing.
Owner info & disposition: Christopher Cifuentes, the victim's great grandson, had been fighting to get his dogs returned to him.

Incident info: Victim was outside watering plants when he was attacked by the dogs. The dogs also attacked a woman trying to aid him, leaving her in hospital with major injuries. The dogs fled when police drove directly towards the woman with lights and sirens on, and were later captured at a nearby residence.
Dog-disposition: The two pit bulls were seized. Both were tranquillized after one of them was extremely aggressive toward animal control. The dogs were ultimately identified as strays.

Reported Breed: dogs (1 Pit bull mix + 1 Shepherd mix + 1 Retriever mix)
Incident info: Victim was mauled to death by her pet dogs. When she was found, two dogs were off of their leashes, and one was tied up. It was speculated that the dogs may have gotten into a fight during feeding, and she may have tried to break up the fight. Autopsy confirmed victim died due to the dog attack.
Dog-disposition: The three dogs were quarantined.

Incident info: Victim was killed by her neighbor's pit bull when she went to her mailbox. A neighbor (who also owns three pit bulls) came to her aid, but the dog attacked her, too. The neighbor tried to jump into a car for protection, but the dog latched onto her arm and began dragging her out. When police arrived, the dog was actively attacking the neighbor, and the victim was dead. An officer dispatched the pit bull by firing three bullets into it.
Dog-disposition: Shot to death by police at the scene. The dog, named Patch, had escaped its home by jumping out of a window 10 feet off the ground when the owner was not home. A few months earlier, it had been declared a nuisance for escaping its property and attacking another dog.
Owner info & disposition: Latisha Young was charged with failure to have her dog vaccinated for rabies.

Incident info: Victim was killed by her own dog when she tried to rescue her mother who was first attacked. The dog also attacked victim's sister. The mother was hospitalized with serious injuries; the sister was treated on scene. Animal control director desribed the scene as horrific.
Dog-disposition: Spike was a male pit bull and had been with the family for 10 years. It tested negative for rabies. Victim's boyfriend said the dog had been aggressive for years and was a contention in their relationship and victim's relationship with her family. The dog had a history of violence including attacking victim's mother just two months earlier.

Incident info: The victim was killed by up to four dogs. Witnesses said she was walking down South Main Street in the small town of Redbird when the animals attacked. One man chased the dogs away, but it was too late. The dogs attacked the woman's face and ripped off all of her clothing. Witnesses said she was left unrecognizable. She died on scene.
Dog-disposition: Authorities seized and quarantined all four dogs.

Incident info: Victim was attacked and killed by a dog as she exited her parked car to pick up her great granddaughters. The dog was sitting on the front stoop of its home. One neighbor who ran to her aid shot the dog causing it to flee into the backyard. Another neighbor, who witnessed the attack from her window, said the horrific onslaught lasted 10-minutes. The victim was rushed to hospital where she died from bite wounds and crushing injuries to her neck, throat and body.
Dog-disposition: Arriving police officers found the pit bull in the backyard and shot it to death.
Owner info & disposition: Leon Morton and Bobbie Green. Seven months after the attack, Leon Morton, 49, pleaded guilty to involuntary manslaughter and was sentenced to 30-months in prison. Bobbie Green, 71, took a plea agreement and pleaded guilty to negligent homicide, a misdemeanor. She was sentenced to 6-months in prison, suspended with 2-years probation. Part of Green's probation includes not owning or caring for any dog.
Legislation info: Family members hope to make legislative changes in pit bull ownership. "We're all going to be very proactive in making sure that what happened to our grandmother does not continue to happen to other people," Tequila said. "What does it take for legislation, for representatives, for the law to see that this is an animal that no matter how kind you are to it, it cannot be controlled?" Williams was the 5th person killed by a pit bull in Ohio in the three years since the state dropped its pit bull law in 2012.

Incident info: Victim was attacked when he climbed the fence to enter his neighbor's yard. He had been climbing over the fence to visit the dog since its arrival, as well to play with his neighbor's young daughter. At the time of the attack, Joshua was home with his mother who was 8-months pregnant. "I went to the bathroom and my boy is dead," she told 911 dispatchers.
Dog-disposition: The pit bull was so aggressive, arriving deputies had to shoot and kill the dog. The neutered male pit bull had been adopted from Asheville Humane Society (AHS) three weeks earlier, previously transfered from Buncombe County shelter, which AHS operates, as a stray with an unknown history.
Legislation info: After the boy's death, Buncombe County officials ordered a moratorium on pit bull "transfers" from the county to AHS and all adoption agencies while they reviewed AHS's temperament test procedures and transfer process. The moratorium was lifted a week later citing that AHS was doing the "industry standard, best practice model for an open admission shelter."

Incident info: Victim was killed by three dogs belonging to his daughter's next door neighbor while feeding his daughter's Labrador Retriever. The neighbor's dogs somehow entered into the backyard and began attacking victim and the labrador. When police arrived, the dogs were still attacking the labrador and a man was lying in the backyard. Police pepper sprayed and tasered the pit bulls to reach the injured man. Victim was pronounced dead.
Dog-disposition: The dogs' owner gave consent to have all three of his dogs put down. The labrador survived its injuries.

Incident info: Victim was at his great-grandmother's house and was playing in the back yard where there were two dogs. The babysitter was watching him through the window. One moment he was fine, the next he was on the ground. The dog had fatally bitten the little boy's throat. The child had been around the dog before without any problems.
Dog-disposition: Police shot the dog on scene who continued to act aggressive after they arrived.

Incident info: Victim was killed by a dog during a visit to his cousin's home. The cousin was not at home at the time of the attack. The dog latched onto the victim's throat and the victim's mother dragged the dog and child outside to get help. Several witnesses intervened and beat the dog with sticks and bricks and also stabbed it, trying to get the dog to let go of the boy. Once the dog let go, they beat the dog to death.
Dog-disposition: The dog was beaten to death during the incident.
Owner info & disposition: Victim's cousin. He was later cited for not having the dog inoculated for rabies and not having a city license. The victim's grandfather was incensed that he was only charged with two minor infractions.

Incident info: Victim was mauled to death by his girlfriend's dog which allegedly assisted the victim when he had epileptic seizures. The dog, however, had previously attacked the victim four times, injuring both ears. Three of those incidents were reported.
Dog-disposition: The dog had been adopted from Rochester Animal Services (previously from a Georgia shelter). This dog had previously attacked Anthony four times; both of his ears had been mauled in separate incidents, three of the incidents were reported to the authorities.

Incident info: The victim and his mother had just arrived at a home to visit friends, when victim went into the backyard. A short time later, his mother found him with severe lacerations. Victim was airlifted to hospital where he died of his injuries.
Dog-disposition: 5 dogs.

Incident info: Victim was killed by his family's dog. The child was sitting in a bouncing seat while the father stepped outside to turn on the sprinklers. When he returned, the dog was attacking in the infant. As the father tried to get the dog off the child, the mother walked in on the scene and was bitten as she tried to intervene. The father dragged the dog outside and shot the dog twice, killing it.
Dog-disposition: The dog was shot and killed by the father. It had been in the family for 8 years, growing up with the two older children, 8 & 11.

Incident info: The victim went to his neighbor's two-home property to feed his cats when a tenant's three dogs jumped the six foot fence and attacked him. Two men ran to help the screaming victim and the dogs attacked them. The men were able to drag the victim next door and close the gate, but the pit bulls found a hole in the fence and resumed the attack. The dogs had chewed off the victim's left hand and his face, leaving an eye hanging out. One of the men got a gun and shot two of the three pit bulls, but the dogs continued attacking, undeterred, until police and EMS arrived, at which point the dogs fled. Authorities arrested the dogs' owner immediately. The victim was airlifted to a hospital in critical condition and died a month later. Both assisting men were seriously injured; one spent 23 days in hospital.
Dog-disposition: The three dogs were caught and put down. The dogs had a history of aggression and being at large.
Owner info & disposition: Ricky Davidson, 40, tenant of the neighbor's house, pleaded guilty to one count of reckless endangerment, a gross misdemeanor. Davidson was sentenced to 364 days in jail in connection to the death of Kenneth Ford. The sentence also included other dog-related and drug-related charges against Davidson that were bundled together in plea negotiations.

Incident info: The woman's body was found in a ditch and autopsy determined she had died from a dog attack. According to the sheriff, there was evidence of a struggle on the ground, with broken yard furniture and scratches, blood, and clothing on the ground."
Dog-disposition: The dogs were never found/identified.
Legislation info: After this mauling death, the sheriff's department and local authorities aggressively responded to all dog calls, hoping to locate the attackers.

Incident info: Victim arrived at an auto shop for a car repair appointment. When he exited his vehicle, seven dogs escaped under the shop gate and attacked him. He ran and got on the roof of his car, but the dogs also got onto the car.
Dog-disposition: Five dogs were shot and killed, 3 more were seized. The dogs had attacked several people previously. One man had to climb a tree to escape. The dog owner's son said there were multiple attack victims from these dogs, and family members had warned his father to "get rid of those dogs".
Owner info & disposition: John Chester Smith, 63, the owner of C.J.'s Garage and the pack of pit bulls, was charged with felony manslaughter, a Class D felony. Prosecutors had evidence there had been four previous serious incidents involving Smith's dogs. Smith pleaded no contest to a felony charge in exchange for a 3-year prison term.

Incident info: The woman was attacked early in the morning near her property while she was out walking. The sheriff arrived and found two people trying to fight off the dog. The victim had 5 children and had spoken with her friend before about the problem dogs.
Dog-disposition: The arriving sheriff shot two of the dogs. The third dog fled but was later captured and put down.
Legislation info: Tribal council members rounded up a few dozen dogs and put them down (including the third attacking dog). There had been a serious aggressive dog problem in the area. They also discussed short and long term strategies to improve animal control on the reservation.

Incident info: Found dead in her home where she lived alone, by her daughter, investigators concluded she had been killed by her dog.
Dog-disposition: The dog was owned by the victim for the previous five years, was surrendered by family members, and euthanized.

Incident info: Victim was killed while trying to revive his roommate, the dog's owner, from a heart attack by slapping his face. Police arrived during the attack and a woman who witnessed the attack was found hiding from the dog on the roof. The dog was not registered with the city, despite ordinance requiring all pit bulls in the city be registered. Both men were pronounced dead at a local hospital. Victim died from a severed radial artery.
Dog-disposition: Sheba, a female pit bull, was sent to South Hills Pet Rescue and Rehabilitation Resort, located in Union Township, Pennsylvania.

Incident info: At her aunt's house, victim was attacked and killed by a family dog. She died from injuries to the head and neck. The father said "I came out of the kitchen and the dog dropped the baby. His name was Jake and my baby was gone."
Dog-disposition: Animal Control impounded Jake, the 3 to 4 year old pit bull-mix that weighs about 80 pound, and it was expected to be euthanized after a 10-day quarantine. The AC officer said Jake tried to attack him when they got to the kennels, was aggressive and uncooperative the night of the attack but had been somewhat withdrawn since. "The dog is still doing the thousand-mile stare. This dog is odd."

Incident info: Found dead by a family member in the woods near his home. Died of exsanguination from dog bites. The victim knew the dogs. The police did not release the number of dogs, their breed, or the owner's name.
Dog-disposition: The dogs were impounded.

Incident info: The boy was attacked in his own yard by two of the family's young dogs he'd known since they were born. His stepfather was inside the house, unawares, and his mother and others were away. When the mother and others returned, they discovered the attack.
Dog-disposition: The attacking dogs were littermates (bred by the victim's parents) about 8 or 9 months old and weighed 25#(F) and 35#(M). They were euthanized along with their dam (who had bitten a 10 year old boy previously), but the family chose to keep the sire of the attacking dogs.
Owner info & disposition: Mother and stepfather of the victim.

Incident info: The victim was playing on his family's porch when the family's two dogs attacked. The grandfather tried, but was unable to pull the dogs off the boy, or each other. Victim was dead by the time the ambulance arrived.
Dog-disposition: Max and Thumper, two male pit bull mixes 18 months and 6 years respectively, had played with the victim many times before and supposedly never shown any aggression to humans but had killed small smaller dogs before. The dogs were seized by animal control.

Incident info: Victim was attacked by the family pit bull while taking down his Christmas tree. The dog was still viciously attacking him when law enforcement and animal control arrived. Victim was transported to hospital where he was pronounced dead on arrival.
Dog-disposition: The victim and his adult son had adopted the neutered male pit bull seven months before. The dog was euthanized. It was 84 pounds and 4 or 5 years old and used to sleep with the victim in his bed.

Incident info: The man died after suffering bites to his arms and face from his dog. His wife came home and found him dead. Officials said an autopsy was not required because it was so obviously death by dog attack. Victim's wife said they had given their two dogs bones on Christmas Eve and that Fatboi the pit bull was extremely aggressive and protective of it. She also said that she had told victim before to euthanize the dog because it was "extremely aggressive and unpredictable."

Victim was found dead after being attacked by five of the seventeen dogs she kept in her home. Described as "a bloody mess" by police, the coroner determined she died of "critical coronary artery atherosclerosis following multiple dog bites". All five dogs were euthanized.

The child was attacked and killed by four of his grandfather's dogs outside in the yard. Animal Control seized and euthanized the dogs.  Both parents appeared under the influence and tested positive for meth, amphetamines, oxy, opiates and benzos. Neighbors told authorities the dogs had been aggressive in the past, including attacking people, and had previously been reported to Animal Control. The neighbors also reported constant drug traffic at the home. Cause of death was ruled "Multiple Blunt Force Injuries due to Dog Mauling" and the victim's two young siblings were placed in foster care. In 2016, the mother pled guilty to Manslaughter of a Child (State of Florida v. Claudia Scarbrough Case# 2014-CF-001350-A) and the father was found not guilty of Murder in the Third Degree by jury (State of Florida v. Christopher Louis Camejo Case# 2014-CF-001350-B).

The elderly woman was attacked on Nov 27 while she was in her yard burning trash, and died four days later due to injuries from the attack which necessitated amputating both legs above the knee. Because the medical examiner didn't find defensive wounds and Ms. Cheveallier was a diabetic, it was thought she was attacked after passing out. Ultimately, 15 dogs were rounded up and euthanized; 14 belonging to the next door neighbor and 1 stray. Their breeds were not disclosed. Two weeks after the attack, the Grant Parish Police Jury unanimously voted to form a committee to explore options for animal control. Alexandria Animal Shelter Superintendent Henry Wimbley and McCain talked to the jurors about possible ordinances and answered questions about dealing with vicious animals and funding for licenses.

Reported Breed: Hounds (6), Australian Cattle Dogs (6) and Heelers (3)
Incident info: Victim was out for a walk when he was attacked by a pack of up to 15 dogs. He died during the attack from a heart attack but had over 100 bites on him. Daniel Douglass McCollum, 55, of Madison was charged with one count of involuntary manslaughter.

The victim was attempting to intervene in a fight between her dog and cat when the dog attacked her. Both of her arms were mutilated. She died four days later. Photos provided of the black and white dog didn't resemble a Keeshond in any way. The dog, which victim had owned for eight years, was seized.
While sledding near her home, the girl was attacked by a pack of dogs. Witnesses to the attack were unsure of how many dogs were involved or what were their breeds.

Woman found unconscious in the cold. Four dogs were on scene when responders arrived. Autopsy ruled the cause of death "exsanguination due to multiple injuries from animal attack consistent with infliction by dogs."

Victim had allowed her granddaughter, 26 yr old Lydia Hoyes, and her four pit bulls to move in about four months previously. They attacked and mutilated the elderly woman while she was sitting on her porch. She died six days later. Other family members had tried to intervene and called police and the Department of Social Service, but the four dogs remained and were allowed to roam a large fenced area, were known to be vicious, and had caused problems in the neighborhood before.

The boy took the dog outside to relieve itself, and within five minutes was attacked. The victim's father was running a protection dog training business; the 3½ year old dog had been trained in "personal property" and was in training for "personal protection and service for a doctor who had three children". The dog was euthanized.

Victim and his elderly mother were both attacked by the neighbor's four dogs who had breached the common fence. The dogs were shot and killed by deputies. The woman received multiple bite injuries and a broken leg; the man did not survive. The dogs' owner moved away right afterwards and no charges were filed.

The elderly woman tripped and fell, then was attacked by her own pitbull. Her daughter was outside and heard her mother say she'd falled. The daughter witnessed the dog biting her mother and called 911. Victim was dead by the time responders arrived, with bite marks on her face, neck, and arms. The dog was put down at the scene.

Attacked by dogs on the side of the road at night and died the following day, but not before he told police what happened to him. Eric Hodges, the owner of these same dogs who also killed Derrick Sanders two months earlier, was sentenced to 20 years in prison for two counts of manslaughter. The dogs were let out to roam at night. Six dogs were seized from Hodges and euthanized.

The boy was found dead in his father's backyard the morning after the father and his girlfriend smoked marijuana laced with cocaine and fell asleep. There were six dogs in the yard. The adults were charged with child neglect. All of the dogs were seized and the pit bull was euthanized for aggressive behavior. Pit bulls are prohibited in Miami-Dade County. Javon Dade Sr pleaded guilty to manslaughter and was sentenced to four years in prison and six years probation in a plea deal.

Grandmother had set down the child after feeding her when the 80# 10-year-old family dog attacked. The victim sustained wounds to the head, back, and stomach. Grandmother, who lost several tips of her fingers trying to save the child, ordered the girl's brothers, 5 and 8 years old, to run for their lives. They ran to the next door neighbor who came and stabbed the dog repeatedly to get it to release. The child was pronounced dead at the hospital. Martel the dog had previously shown aggressive behavior and was euthanized. Derek Martin Solem, 32, and Sharon D. Williams, 29, were charged with two felonies each, endangering the welfare of a child and owning a dog that bites a person resulting in death.

Babysitting aunt, Heather Claar, let the child and the two dogs outside her house and sat to watch TV. She checked on him 10-15 minutes later and saw his body in the driveway. After the attack, the dogs were seized by animal control and euthanized. Four other dogs on the property were also seized - a pit bull, 2 catahoula leopards and a plott hound. The attacking dogs and the boy were familiar with each other.

Victim was mauled to death by her daughter's pit bull. Was playing with her 2-year-old grandson in the yard when the dog attacked. A neighbor beat the dog off with a walking stick, but she was already dead with multiple wounds to the head, neck, and body. The dog had not shown previous aggression; the child used to climb and put weight on the dog. The dog, Polo, was euthanized. No charges were filed against the owner, Julie Whisman.

The victim was out jogging. A neighbor who witnessed the attack successfully drove off the two 100# dogs after wounding one with a gun. Dogs at the same address had attacked and bitten two other people (in 2012 and 2013) who were walking or jogging in the neighborhood. Sebastiano Quagliata, 46, and his wife, Valbona Lucaj, 45, were sentenced to 57 months to 15 years in prison after pleading no contest to "owning a dangerous animal, causing death", and received prison sentences for a minimum of 57 months to a maximum of 15 years. The couple may also face deportation, as they were under investigation for falsifying citizenship documents at the time of the mauling. At the time of the attack, the couple owned 3 Cane Corso adults and 8 puppies.

The boy's step-grandmother picked the boy up from a car seat and then the dog jumped and bit the boy and the woman. The woman tried punching the dog and grabbing its collar but then the dog bit the boy's head. The dog had prior behavioral issues. The dog was seized and euthanized. The step-grandmother, Kimiko Hardy, 37, was sentenced to three years in prison in June 2016.

Mauled to death by his uncle's guard dogs after being left unsupervised while his parents left to consume cannabis. The boy's grandmother said that the family knew the dogs were vicious. Neighbors also said that the dogs were known to be vicious. Although early speculations stated that the child may have let the dogs out of their cages to play with, family members later stated that the uncle, Billy Fredericks Sr., had left the dogs free to roam the yard to protect his property.

Found dead, naked, throat split, and in a horrible state, police originally thought victim was murdered - until two months later when the victim's cousin David Glass was found barely alive, mauled by pit bulls. Eric Hodges, the owner of these same dogs who also killed David Glass two months later, was sentenced to 20 years in prison for two counts of manslaughter. The dogs were let out to roam at night; both were euthanized.

When the dog tried to get on the sofa where the baby was on his uncle's lap, the uncle pushed it off. The dog then attacked, biting the baby on the face and neck. Father was injured prying him out of its jaws. EMTs tried to revive the baby and airlifted him to the hospital, where he was pronounced dead. Prior to the attack, the dog had lived with the family for over two years. It had bitten a person once, but had drawn no blood. The dog was euthanized.

Victim was out walking on April 13 when the dog bolted out of its owner's back door and went straight for the elderly woman. The owner had to beat the dog on the head with a rock and a baseball bat to get it to let go of the victim's leg. The victim died in hospital a month later. The dog had been adopted from the local animal shelter 7 months previously as a 16 month old 60# dog.

The child had gone with his pregnant mother to visit one of the mother's friends and was playing in front of the home with the dogs, with which he had reportedly played with in the past. The mother went inside to go to the bathroom and when she returned the three pit bulls were attacking the child. The mother sustained injuries trying to save her son. Nearby HVAC workers attempted to beat the dogs back with PVC pipes and were unsuccessful. The child was pronounced dead on scene by paramedics, the mother was taken to the hospital for treatment of injuries and monitoring of the unborn child. The dogs, a female pit bull and her two one-year-old offspring, had not been vaccinated against rabies and were euthanised.

Victim was killed by a chained dog his grandfather had acquired just three weeks prior. Ervin Patterson, the boy's grandfather, was sleeping when he heard his 5-year old grandson screaming. He ran outside and found the dog laying on the body of the child.

Victim had gone to her friends yard in preparation for dog-sitting. They'd been with the dogs for about three hours and were playing fetch when the victim bent down to pick up a ball and was attacked. She suffered extensive bite wounds over her body and a severe head injury (she was entirely scalped) and died about a week later. The dogs were quarantined, and later Steve Klemetti and his wife Victoria Klemetti surrendered the dogs, which were euthanized.

Victim was found dead of methamphetamine intoxication and canine bites. Investigators concluded that three pit bulls, owned by Lisa Hodge and her recently deceased husband Floyd Gene Hodge, were responsible. The dogs were highly aggressive and neighbors had reported that the dogs were vicious including jumping into their yards and lunging into windows at people inside their houses. The dogs were euthanized.

Victim was feeding cats in her own backyard when the neighbor's dogs crawled under a fence and attacked her. She died two weeks later. One dog, Skirtgles, who had previously bitten a child, was euthanized and the other two dogs returned. The dog's owner, Perla Rojas-Ibarra, 34, was sentenced to five years in prison.

Playing outside his home when the 80-100# neighbor's dog attacked. His 9-year-old brother saw the attack and jumped in with his bicycle, but couldn't get the dog off him, so he ran in the house and got his father, who shot at the animal several times, breaking off the attack and fleeing. He was pronounced dead at the hospital. The dog was seized and euthanized. A grand jury indicted the owner of a pit bull, Johnny Ray Kay Sr., 57, on a misdemeanor charge of criminally negligent homicide.

A woman was found dead at her home by her son. When police arrived, there were two large very aggressive pit bulls loose which should have been locked inside a bedroom. It looked as though they broke down the door in order to attack the woman. Authorities seized the two offending pit bulls and another 6 pit bulls that were being kept in substandard pens outside. All were considered aggressive and they were slated for euthanasia.

Christopher Malone's mother found the dogs on her son behind the family's home. She tried to stop the dogs and got bitten in the process. The dogs, owned by family members, had escaped their chain link pen. Sheriff March voiced his support for a countywide ban on pit bulls after the boy's death which heated up after a 4 year old child was mauled by family pit bulls just ten days later.

Family's pet pit bull attacked while she was watching television with her mother. The mother, also injured, had to barricade herself and the injured child in a bedroom and had the child to EMTs through the window. Responding officers shot the pit bull three times through a window and then again when they entered the apartment. The dog, Niko, was of an unusually large size, weighing in at 130 lbs. The victim's family, including the mother and her boyfriend (who owned the dog) has refused cooperation with authorities into further investigation. Another dog, a 6-month-old female, was removed from the scene.
Victim was feeding 4-year old Titan, one of the family's three dogs, when he bit her in the abdomen. The dog had a history of aggression and biting people, and was euthanized per family request.

Walking home from the playground with an 8-year-old girl, when the dog escaped from his owner's garage and attacked the girl. A teenage boy saved the girl, but then the dog immediately attacked Raymane and dragged him off. Someone shot at the dog, frightening it into dropping the boy and running back into the garage. Police and EMTs arrived and took them both to the hospital, where doctors saved the girl but the boy died of penetrating and blunt injuries. The parents hope their son's death encourages officials to change state law regarding vicious dog attacks and have launched a dog violence prevention website at noviciousdogs.com.

A 115-pound bull mastiff escaped from a neighboring property and attacked two 13-year-old boys in the street, killing one and severely injuring the other. The owner stabbed the dog several times, getting bitten in the mele, and the dog was put down by animal control. Later, the dog owner "lawyered up" and refused to talk to investigating police.
Killed by a loose dog belonging to a neighbor while playing behind the trailer her grandfather rented. The dog was seized.

Was playing in her yard when her family's dog suddenly attacked. Her mother tried to stop it, but the dog attacked her as well. The family said the dog had never been aggressive, but neighbors said it had escaped and attacked a dog. Both mother and daughter were taken to the hospital, where Braelynn died. The dog was taken by authorities and scheduled to be euthanized after police finished their investigation.

The girl's family was watching a friend's female dog and its two puppies. They were being kept in the back yard. The 2-year-old girl went out into the yard alone without her parent's knowledge and was attacked by the mother of the two puppies. The dog was chained in the backyard at the time, was later euthanized, and no criminal charges were to be filed.

The woman was attacked in the driveway of her home in the early morning hours by two mastiffs that belonged to a neighbor. The dogs were shot and killed when they attacked police officers who responded to the call. The couple who owned the dogs were each found guilty of two misdemeanor counts of failure to control dogs. Andrew Nason, 30, was sentenced to 150 days in jail, 500 hours of community service, a $500 fine and court costs. Julie Custer, 27, was sentenced to 90 days in jail, 480 hours of community service, a $200 fine and court costs. A wrongful death suit was filed against the county dog warden and his agency. The victim had made 36 calls to authorities about the dogs over the prior two years before her death (in addition to 20 other anonymous calls), built a fence and installed security cameras. Richey's death sparked several attempts (still ongoing) to change the vicious dog laws in Ohio.

The dogs belonged to the woman's grandson. He told police they had no history of aggressive behavior. Arriving police officers shot one rottweiler to death after the dogs lunged at them; the other two dogs were confiscated and euthanized.

Died from blood loss following injuries sustained to head and neck after being attacked by the dogs while her grandmother was babysitting Kara and her 2-year-old sister. When the grandmother attempted to intervene, the dogs turned on her and she then focused on protecting the 2-year-old child and was unable to stop the attack on Kara. Emergency personnel were called and Kara was taken to a hospital but died from her injuries. The dogs were surrendered to McLean County Animal Control where they were euthanized after a 10-day observation period. No charges were filed against the owners.

December 21, 2013, an rlderly widow was walking alone when the neighbor's dogs badly mauled her. She was saved by another neighbor and her boyfriend, who used a gun to scare off the dogs, but not before receiving wounds that caused her death in the hospital 16 days later. After the attack, the dogs were euthanized and their owners were arrested for allowing a dog attack that resulted in a death. The attack was first reported in the news media 4 months after the incident in an article about an unrelated attack. The dog's owners were indicted and arrested in 2014 for "Attack by dog resulting in death". Five years later, they were acquitted by jury trial May 6, 2019 (State of Texas vs. Rachelle Kay Lucas CR2014-315 and State of Texas vs. Peter Scott Lucas CR2014-316).

Killed by loose dogs in an attack in which two other people were also injured, one seriously. Animal Control caught one of the dogs, while the owner fled with the second dog, a pit bull mix. Later the owner surrendered the second dog plus a third dog not believed to be part of the killing. The owners of the dogs were cited for keeping the animals in deplorable conditions, not licensing or vaccinating them, and allowing them to run at large. Timothy Dewayne Coleman, 33, and Tiara Deshawn Thomas, 26, who owned at least one of the attacking pit bulls, are being charged under the state felony dog attack law.

The victim tried to break up a fight amongst their dogs when one dog, the Boxer, turned on him, and the others joined in. Victim’s wife tried to intervene and was herself injured. Of their six dogs, a Cocker Spaniel was killed in the melee. The wife requested that the remaining five dogs (a German Shepherd, a Boxer, and three Boxer-mixes) be euthanized.

Mauled to death by one of her own dogs. Her son came home and found the dog on top of her; he shot and killed it. It seems she had gone outside to the dog pen to break ice on the water bowls. They had 12 pit bulls on the property; at least 4 others were surrendered and euthanized.
Injured by her family’s two dogs while her parents slept. Mia was a premature baby who had only recently come home from the hospital.
The girl was attacked by her grandfather’s dogs in his home. Her death was ruled a homicide and family members gathered outside the grandfather’s home demanding he be held accountable for her death.

The victim was attacked while taking a walk in a gated, retirement community. One of the dog’s owners had let the dog out, unsupervised, in an unsecured yard. The owner of the 87# dog said it would frequently "bite out of fear". It had previously bitten an intoxicated family member in the face, bitten a neighbor in the face, and bitten its owner on the arm and leg. It was discovered that the dog was a littermate of the dog that killed Ayden Even on June 9, 2013.  Charges were filed.

Victim was attacked while visiting another home with his mother. The boy managed to slip out of the house unnoticed, entering a fenced-in area where three pit bulls were being held. When discovered, his mother tried to resuscitate him, but it was too late. Three dogs were seized and quarantined, and later they were destroyed at the owner’s request.

Out for a walk, the dogs attacked her from behind. Witnesses tried to intervene, eventually shooting one dog and police shooting the other. Her arm was shredded. She died six days later in hospital from a heart attack brought on by "extremity contusions, lacerations and fractures due to dog bites".

Went out to the kennel behind their home to feed the dogs as usual, but this time they attacked. They belonged to her boyfriend but the victim had been around the dogs since they were puppies. The dogs were surrendered and euthanized.

Victim originally acquired the dog for protection and had raised it from a puppy. It had previously attacked a family member and Douglass, who carried a large facial scar as a result. The dog had been seized by authorities, but Douglass had fought to get the dog back, and it had recently been returned to her. Her family pleaded with Animal Control to not return the dog, and with the landlord to ban it. Six months later the dog fatally attacked her.
The boy was visiting at a family friend's house. The dog had been acquired 6 weeks earlier.

Killed by up to five of his grandmother’s dogs in her backyard. The boy was found dead with bite marks to his face and neck. Neighbors had complained to authorities about the noise and "stench from the yard" where the dogs were kept. Eight dogs were seized. The grandmother and an uncle were arrested. Charges were filed against the uncle.

Toddler was killed by 3 dogs owned by his babysitter, who was also babysitting in her home his four other siblings, all special needs. The babysitter was also mauled and hospitalized trying to break up a fight between the dogs. The dogs were euthanized for rabies testing.
Jordan was found dead after being mauled by one or more loose dogs. The town had a problem with loose dogs.

Victim was found dead in his backyard, with one of his lower legs missing, bites all over his body, his pet dog dead, and three pit bull type dogs nearby. Five dogs were seized from the area. They were thought to belong to the rear neighbor whose wooden fence had some broken slats.

Victim was killed by a dog that she had taken in as a stray two weeks previously. The incident occurred while she was attempting to stop it from attacking her other "small brown wiener dog." Deputies shot the dog twice and it fled. Two days later it was found and shot to death.
Killed after walking up to a chained dog that belonged to her aunt. The dog, plus two more pit bulls, were seized. The attacking dog was euthanized.
The boy was attempting to ride the dog "like a horse" when he was bitten a single time on the top of the head. The victim’s mother said the boy and dog were “best friends”.

Killed inside the home of family friends where he had been staying. After the child had started loudly crying, the 150 lb. dog came running out of a back room and attacked him. The dog's owner stopped the attack, but not before the boy had received serious wounds to the head, neck and face. He was rushed to a hospital where he was declared dead. The dog ran away but was found and shot the following day by a neighbor.

Freeman, a bi-lateral amputee at the knees, was driving in his wheelchair when he was attacked by a pack of four dogs that neighbors said had been roaming the neighborhood on-and-off for months. He tried to fight the dogs, but was unable to and was pulled from his wheelchair. The incident happened on May 8, and Freeman died on May 12. The coroner says he had lacerations and bites "from his legs to the top of his head." Initial reports said that three of the dogs belonged to a woman who is Freeman's neighbor and relative.
The woman was walking near her home when she was attacked by a pack of dogs. DNA results later confirmed that four of the eight dogs owned by a local man had been involved in the attack.
Owner info & disposition: The owner of the dogs, Alex Jackson, 29, was charged with second degree murder for the attack. He was also charged with assault with a deadly weapon for a previous incident in which his dogs attacked a horse and rider and he threw a stone at the rider. He also faced several charges related to a marijuana growing operation he was running. The dogs had been involved in several other attacks for which the owner was cited, and he had also been cited for failing to vaccinate, license, spay, neuter or microchip the dogs.

After the attack, the dogs were euthanized and tested negative for rabies, and the authorities decided not to press charges against the babysitter.
